t: Proverbs 21
On Life and Conduct
The*pn king’s heart is like*i channels of water in the hand of the Lord;*s He*ln turns it wherever He wishes.
Every*ln man’s way is right in his own eyes, But*ln the Lord*s weighs the hearts.
To*ln do righteousness and justice Is*ln desired by the Lord*s more than sacrifice.
Haughty*ln eyes and a proud heart, The*ln lamp of the wicked, is sin.
The*ln plans of the diligent lead*i surely to advantage, But*ln everyone who is hasty comes*i surely to poverty.
The*ln acquisition of treasures by a lying tongue Is*ln a fleeting vapor, the pursuit of death.
The*ln violence of the wicked will drag them away, Because*ln they refuse to act with justice.
The*ln way of a guilty man is crooked, But*ln as for the pure, his conduct is upright.
It*ln is better to live in a corner of a roof Than*ln in a house shared with a contentious woman.
The*ln soul of the wicked desires evil; His*ln neighbor finds no favor in his eyes.
When*ln the scoffer is punished, the naive becomes wise; But*ln when the wise is instructed, he receives knowledge.
The*ln righteous one considers the house of the wicked, Turning*ln the wicked to ruin.
He*ln who shuts his ear to the cry of the poor Will*ln also cry himself and not be answered.
A*ln gift in secret subdues anger, And*ln a bribe in the bosom, strong wrath.
The*ln exercise of justice is joy for the righteous, But*ln is terror to the workers of iniquity.
A*ln man who wanders from the way of understanding Will*ln rest in the assembly of the dead.
He*ln who loves pleasure will*i become*i a poor man; He*ln who loves wine and oil will not become rich.
The*ln wicked is a ransom for the righteous, And*ln the treacherous is in the place of the upright.
It*ln is better to live in a desert land Than*ln with a contentious and vexing woman.
There*ln is precious treasure and oil in the dwelling of the wise, But*ln a foolish man swallows it up.
He*ln who pursues righteousness and loyalty Finds*ln life, righteousness and honor.
A*ln wise man scales the city of the mighty And*ln brings down the stronghold in which they trust.
He*ln who guards his mouth and his tongue, Guards*ln his soul from troubles.
“Proud,”*ln “Haughty,” “Scoffer,” are his names, Who*ln acts with insolent pride.
The*ln desire of the sluggard puts him to death, For*ln his hands refuse to work;
All*ln day long he is craving, While*ln the righteous gives and does not hold back.
The*ln sacrifice of the wicked is an abomination, How*ln much more when he brings it with evil intent!
A*ln false witness will perish, But*ln the man who listens to*i the*i truth*i will speak forever.
A*ln wicked man displays a bold face, But*ln as for the upright, he makes his way sure.
There*ln is no wisdom and no understanding And*ln no counsel against the Lord.*s
The*ln horse is prepared for the day of battle, But*ln victory belongs to the Lord.*s
